As I indicated earlier, we are going to progress only those amendments that were supported previously by the Senate. Essentially, we believe that the government's proposals go too far in enhancing the powers of departmental secretaries and turning Public Service agencies into independent entities. As I have said, they do not go far enough in protecting the independence and professionalism of the Public Service and the working conditions of public servants.

The point of these amendments is to address that imbalance. They deal with a number of key concerns that we have with these bills. I mention some important ones for the benefit of the committee. One is in relation to the power of secretaries. Our amendments here limit the powers of secretaries in a number of ways. There is a clause setting out their responsibilities, including assisting the minister to fulfil his or her accountability obligations to parliament. There is a prohibition on cosy deals on salary and conditions. Salaries are to be set on the advice of the Remuneration Tribunal and published in the Gazette so that they will be open to public scrutiny. Secretaries are to be subject to sanctions for breaches of the code of conduct in the same way as employees.

The prevention of patronage and cronyism is another important issue which the Senate spent a great deal of time debating previously. The bill proscribes patronage and favouritism, but we say its provisions will actually encourage those things. You have got political appointments at the top. These are appointees who might well be lured by special deals into the Australian Public Service. You have got an SES that is dependent on patronage for its survival and employees who are heavily dependent on their bosses for their salaries and conditions of service, and also with restricted rights of appeal. So the bill does not actually provide for sanctions against patronage and favouritism, and the amendments that the opposition are moving remedy that situation.

We are also proposing in our amendments to ensure that merit is the sole consideration in a decision to engage or promote an employee. The independence of SES employees will be protected by requiring the Public Service Commissioner to certify that termination is in accordance with the published procedures and in the best interests of the APS, and by giving them access to the unfair dismissals provisions of the Workplace Relations Act.

The issue of the rights of employees of the Australian Public Service is another one that has been widely canvassed during our previous committee stage debate. It is an important one for the opposition. That is why we have proposed a large number of amendments which are designed to protect the interests of APS employees. That includes: the changes to the values to entrench the right to be represented by unions; appropriate training and development opportunities; the ability to participate in decision making; provisions to ensure greater transparency in management decisions relating to breaches of the code of conduct and termination; the protection of current appeal rights and the independence and powers of the Merit Protection Commissioner; maintenance of conditions of employment as set out in current awards and certified agreements until such time as new conditions are agreed to; and of course the protection of mobility rights for those public servants who currently have them.

Another important issue is the Merit Protection Commissioner. I know this is something that has been of very great concern to Senator Cooney, who has canvassed this issue on a number of occasions. The government reluctantly agreed to maintain the Merit Protection Commissioner as an independent statutory authority, but did not include in the legislation or in the draft regulations on review of actions the necessary functions, the necessary powers, the necessary protections for the commissioner to be fully independent and effective. Our amendments seek to restore these powers and protections to the commissioner.

It is necessary to point out to the committee during this committee stage debate the opposition's strong belief that the government is taking devolution of powers to individual agencies too far. It does not make sense for agencies to be reinventing the wheel in areas of commonality, such as adherence to the values and code of conduct and procedures for breaches, engagement and termination of SES employees. Our amendments therefore provide for the Public Service Commissioner to provide guidance in the form of directions to all agencies in these areas.

We are concerned that executive agencies, which the government wishes to set up under this legislation, will be less accountable than departments. We have proposed an amendment to ensure that they are as accountable as departments to the government, to the parliament and to the public. As I have indicated, I think these are important principles. I have also said that for the convenience of the Senate we do not think it is necessary to have a re-run of the very lengthy committee debate that occurred on the last occasion these matters were before the Senate. Obviously they were thoroughly canvassed previously. It is for that reason that I propose to deal with the amendments in this way.

In relation to the amendments to the Public Service Bill, the committee will find that those amendments are identical to those that were proposed by the opposition and passed by the Senate in November last year. When we deal with the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 [No. 2] , I would like to point out to the committee one small difference that has emerged since that time.

talk.start.para: âI also would like to add some general comments with respect to the Public Service Bill 1997 [No. 2] . It is unfortunate and disappointing that we find ourselves once more facing a piece of government legislation based on an expression of the government's vindictiveness towards Australian workers. The Public Service Bill will, in effect, sever the relationship between the federal governmentâin its delivery of services and its formulation and preparation of policy to the Australian peopleâand a strong, independent Public Service operating alongside a healthy private sector. Rather than pursuing the goal of having an independent public sector playing an essential role in the promotion of social and economic policy delivery, the government's plan is indeed to undermine that cohesion and undermine the accountability of the Australian Public Service.

speech.para: Indeed, just through my experience in the estimates committee process over the last two years, I have found the changing nature of the Public Service under this government to be quite significantâto the point where the salaries of the more senior public servants are determined outside of public scrutiny, where more and more often we see the policy processes hidden behind veils of secrecy and the introduction of outsourcing not as a mechanism to improve efficiencies but as a blanket formula for screening parliamentary scrutiny of the way this government expends taxpayers' dollars.

Another major feature of this government's attitude towards the public sector is the absolute ignorance they have of what motivates many of the individuals within the Australian Public Service. Contrary to the assumptions of this government, who presume that all Australians are motivated by greed, by money, by their level of remuneration or their career opportunityâI speak on behalf of those thousands upon thousands of public servants who choose to be in the service of the publicâthey choose to spend their careers working on behalf of all Australians. With this choice brings some sacrifice, but it also used to bring some job security. This was part of the environment people entered if they chose to devote their life to the service of the public.

This philosophy is not understood by this government in any respect. They think that everyone has to be motivated by the dollar. It is why outsourcing, they argue, is such a lucrative opportunity for public servants who can transfer their employ from the public to the private sector. They do not mention the very large percentage of people who lose their jobs in the process. They do not mention that a very high proportion of any savings arising from any outsourcing arrive only because of the loss of jobs and the savings in the wages bills that subsequently result.

The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business talks about efficiencies, competitiveness and autonomy without any regard to what type of service will be delivered. Despite the rhetoric emanating from those opposite, we have yet to hear how this new Public Service will deliver honest and impartial advice without fear or favour. We are seeing a bill and mechanisms that will change the Public Service. They will change its nature. The Public Service is not the whimsical creation of some clever politicians. The Public Service has evolved over many years and was indeed in a state of evolution when this bill came forward.

The record of Labor's efforts on restructuring the public sector are well documented. Some features of that process were more worthy than others, but at least at the core was a commitment to a strong public sector and an acceptance of the role that the public sector plays in Australian life. Missing from this government's rhetoric is exactly what type of Public Service we will end up with. Will they achieve compliance by taking away the traditional career path of Australian public servants? Will they achieve compliance by politicising the APS and devaluing the corporate memory of the service?

And how do we value that corporate memory? I do not see any quantification in any savings outcomes in the government's calculations in their pursuit of efficiencies. How do we quantify that? How do we quantify years and years of experience in managing public policy? We cannot quantify it. Unless it is factored in, it is a false equation. Unless that corporate knowledge is given some value, it does not matter what this government prepare on paperâit will be a false representation of the value of that service.

The government alleges that these reforms will create a dynamic and flexible Public Service. Far from it. This new Public Service will struggle to deliver a political knowledge and expertise given that its cohesion, morale, independence, career opportunities and quality of service are being systematically eroded by this legislation. I remind those opposite that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts concluded that the changes contained in this legislation would not necessarily result in simplification; rather, they will result in increased inequities and inconsistencies across the various organisations and between employees.

I do not believe this bill is in the national interest. We do not need or want a Public Service that is beholden to the political whims of whichever government is in office. I think a particularly relevant comment to make is that a government who is so prone to bad decision making cannot indeed afford to compromise the advice they receive.

I would like to revisit the point about tenure. Removing the security of tenure and the possibility of permanency will not achieve an independent Public Service either. The fact that the APS is no longer viewed as a career path will seriously undermine its ability to recruit the type of people needed to safeguard its independence. Certainly my experience within the private sector shows that many of the strategies put in place by industry lend themselves to establishing a more comprehensive, more predictable career path. Yet, in the Public Service, this government sees fit to go in the opposite direction. I do not think there is too much wisdom backing this approach.

It is ironic, given this government's commitment, so they claim, to the private sector, that this time they choose not to look to the lessons of private industry and see the investment in establishing stable career pathsâwith varying degrees of success, but you cannot deny that that has been the aim and the goal: to improve recruitment and to retain those with experience who can add value to their particular sector.

I would like to conclude by conveying a story about a public servant here in the ACT. It is a story about somebody who had many options in their career. They were quite experienced, had worked in both the public and private sectors and had operated as a consultant, being self-employed.

When faced with a choice of a range of positions, this person chose to work in the Public Service because he felt that he could do the most good for his country in that capacity. This individual's choice to work in the public sector was motivated, I believe, by a genuine desire to contribute something to the greater good. The appeal of the private sector or the lure of the big consultancy dollar was not enough to change this person's career choice.

However, six months into this position he found out that that particular area in that particular department was going to be abolished. Why? He still does not know why. It was part of that department's downsizing and pursuit of efficiencies. As a result, the public sector has lost a great contributor. His corporate knowledge was not valued; his contribution was not valued. In fact, he was treated most appallingly in the process that led to the winding up of that particular section.

The Australian Public Service used to be a proud organisation that valued its contributors. It is now an organisation of low morale and many devastated people who have believed in their contribution over the years and believed in work that they were doing.

Whilst I have not been concentrating my remarks on some of the technical clauses of the bill, these issues are not spoken about enough in this place. It is about commitment to the collective, it is about acknowledging the genuine role of the public sector in this country and it is about acknowledging the fact that unless this parliament safeguards everything that the public sector stands for in its independence, pride and ability, no-one else is going to do it. They are in our hands, and this government has forsaken that responsibility in pursuit of a cheap and shallow ideology. Unfortunately, whilst they are in power, the role of the Public Service and what it brings to Australia will be diminished.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the adjournment on a serious matter, something on which the government has shown very great and gross hypocrisy; that is, the use by the Howard government in a very partisan way of taxpayers' funds for party political purposes. This is the taxpayer funded propaganda service courtesy of the Department of Finance and Administration, the government members secretariat. I want to focus on some promotional material that has been provided tonight to the opposition from the government members secretariat. This material is presented first in a format with a cover sheet that is headed `Promotional Material'. I will quote quickly from it as follows:

speech.para: Please find the following additional promotional material that has been prepared by the Government Members Secretariat for use in your electorateâ

Please note that your authorisation already appears on each flyer.
Its says:

The A4 size flyer could be used in newsletters or as handouts at street stalls. The DL size flyer could be inserted in all your correspondence and could also be used in street stalls and these should be photocopied on bright coloured paper.

âIn contrast to the negative whining, carping, pinpricking, muckraking approach of Labor, as demonstrated by the previous speech of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner), tonight I want to speak of real Australians doing positive things for their country. I speak of those who are happily working away because they are doing what really matters, what Australians are really concerned about: looking after their environment for themselves and their descendants.

speech.para: A couple of Saturdays ago, at the invitation of Councillor Geraldine Knapp of the Brisbane City Council, I had the pleasure of visiting a project that a number of Brisbane people are involved in: saving and repairing the waterways in the Brisbane City area. Those people belong to a group called SOWN, which stands for Save Our WaterwaysâNow! The project that I visited has been going for some time; the former councillor for the area, Mr Brian Hallinan, also initiated it in years gone by. I was accompanied in my inspection of this work by a couple of people who are very much committed to the project: a Mr Bob Whiteman, who is President of SOWN; and Mr Brian Sait, who is the coordinator of the project.

This project was developed to provide a working model of waterways management, with an emphasis on ongoing maintenance. It is presently being developed in Brisbane's western suburbs in 28 square kilometres of the catchments of the Enoggera, Ithaca and Fish Creek systems, which join together to form Breakfast Creek. The creeks draining this part of the Brisbane area are over 23 kilometres in length. The 46 kilometres of creek banks, plus hundreds of kilometres of usually dry gullies, had been allowed to become totally degraded, caused by citizens dumping garden cuttings of vines and exotics over many years and because of the council's inability to carry out corrective maintenance.

This SOWN project is to rectify some longstanding environmental concerns that residents have had about the state of Enoggera and Ithaca Creeks. It is a solid example of the federal government, local governments and the community working together to clean up Australia's waterways. In the last year alone some 20,000 native trees and grasses were planted, with 900 cubic of metres of mulch being spread. The strength of the project has been the work by 700 or so volunteers, who have contributed more than 68,000 volunteer hours since the project's inception three years ago.

The federal government, through the Natural Heritage Trust, has committed some $56,800 to return the creeks to their natural state. This funding ensures the future viability of the project for another three years. The project is not only an example of our Natural Heritage Trust working but also of other government programs working together.

The SOWN project has had the assistance of a Green Corps team. As parliamentary secretary responsible for the Green Corps, I am proud that the local Green Corps team was able to assist the SOWN project last November. The Green Corps team dedicated time to identifying weeds and removing large amounts of Tecoma stans and Ochna from areas surrounding the creeks.

The government's work for the dole scheme has also been of benefit to the project, with teams funded by the scheme and organised by the Moreton Bay Marine Association being allocated to assist on this project. This project is a classic example of Australians working together with their governments to get real outcomes and returns for the environmentâand, through that, for their country.

I have a few extra minutes, so I will just mention another good news story. That concerns, up my way in North Queensland, a group called the North Queensland Joint Board. It is rather an odd sort of name, but it is a combinationâa cooperative getting together of local governments in Far North Queensland. These local governments have got together to become involved in environmental repair work, particularly tree planting, and in the wet tropics vegetation management program.

The councils involved include the Atherton Shire, Cairns City, Cardwell Shire, Cook Shire, Douglas Shire, Eacham Shire, Herberton Shire, Hinchinbrook Shire, Johnstone Shire and Mareeba Shire. For 1997-98 the projects being undertaken by the North Queensland Joint Board total some $1,455,166, with the federal government's Natural Heritage Trust again playing a major role in the money allocated for those projects.

The projects right across Far North Queensland look at things like fixing up degraded scrub areas, maintenance and repair of creek banks, maintenance of remnant vegetation, a lot of riparian work, a good deal of work being done on the foreshores, and an amount of money being spent in the Cardwell Shire and the Johnstone Shire for wildlife corridorsâand that principally is to enable the cassowary, an endangered species, to be able to move with some safety in that Mission Beach area of Far North Queensland.

The people doing those wildlife corridors are working in close conjunction with another initiative of this government that Senator Hill was instrumental in setting up, and that was a grant of some $200,000 to establish a foundation to look after the endangered cassowary.

In addition to wildlife corridors, there is a lot of very good work going on throughout Far North Queensland under the auspices of the North Queensland Joint Board. This is a classic example of the Commonwealth government working with the local governments in this case and with the general community in getting real and positive things done for our environment, repairing some of the degradation that has happened over the years.

It does show that this government can rightly claim to be the greenest government ever to govern in Australia. The previous government used to talk about the environment. They did a lot in a political sense to get the second preferences of so-called green candidates several years ago, but it was all talk. There was never any particular action. I am proud to be part of a government that has put its money where its mouth is, so to speak, and has invested over $1 billion in the environment. All this work will help not only this generation but also generations of Australians to come.
These are just two examples of the great things being done around our countryside by Australians in conjunction with their governments. They are good news stories that need to be told.

talk.start.para: âTonight I want to say a few further words on the report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee inquiry into sexual discrimination. The report was delivered in this place in December of last year. It is unusual in the sense that it is a report on a private member's bill by a references committee. What is even more unusual is the amount of interest that the report and its contents have generated since its presentation in this place.

speech.para: I have not quite been inundated but I have certainly received an enormous amount of mail on the subject of the content of the report. Although I have not counted them, around 98 per cent of the letters I have received have come from the state of Queensland, despite the fact that I am a representative of Western Australia. I am a Western Australian senator, yet they are writing to me about it.

I must apologise to all of the people from Queensland and from other parts of Australia who have written to me because I do not have the time, the staff or the resources to respond to all of them. My resources go into representing the state that I have been elected to represent and very rarely do I respond to letters and correspondence from other states. I just do not have the resources to do it and my staff are too busy serving the electorate of Western Australia. I do appreciate people writing to me but, unfortunately, if they are not from my state I am not in a position to directly respond to them.

I trust then that the people who have a deep and inherent interest in the content of the report, so much so that they have written to me, will accept this explanation as an apology for me not getting back to them directly. I do assure all constituents in Western Australia, however, that if they do write to me they will get a response. They might not, on every occasion, like the response that they get but they will get a direct, frank and, very importantly, honest response.

I say `honest' because I am afraid what has been happening in the debate on the report and its contents has not been entirely honest. The report is not about bringing about the end of the world in any shape or by any means or methods. It is not about that at all, yet there has been somewhat of a scare campaign run in the community, particularly in the state of Queensland, about the report. One would think, from the fear that has been generated in people's minds, as expressed in bundles of letters such as this, that if the report were implemented it would virtually mean the end of civilisation in that state as we know it. Nothing could be further from the truth.

The report is, as I said in the very beginning, a review of a private member's bill that was introduced into this parliament by former Senator Sid Spindler of the Australian Democrats. Senator Spindler was able to convince the majority of the Senate to refer this bill to the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee for inquiry. That was done on 30 May 1996. The committee held public hearings in practically every capital city of the nation and received a very large number of submissionsâsome 436 in number, which is more than you would receive on the average bill coming through this place.

We deliberated on the bill for an extensive period of time in formulating the report. It is a very considered reportânot a unanimous report by any stretch of the imagination, but nevertheless a very considered reportâwhich put forward 33 recommendations for amendment to the bill. It is a private member's bill and it is up to those who move a private member's bill to either accept, reject or modify those recommendations that are put to them by a committee.

The committee's work has been done. I thank all of my colleagues on the committee and the secretariat. I believe it was a job well done even though I am, to a certain extent, patting myself on the back as chair of the committee. It is not my intention to do so. I do not need to do so because I think the report speaks for itself.

The first thing that happened was that it was alleged in some circles that we were recommending in the report that certain transgender people be able to compete openly in women's sports. I had this to say on that particular element of the report on 2 December:

The report makes no recommendations about sport. The evidence did not demonstrate that there was much interest in competitive sport by transgender persons and the Committee considers this issue can be dealt with by the relevant sporting organisations on a case by case basis.

I invite anybody to pick up the report and point to the recommendations where the committee said that transgender persons would be allowed to compete openly in womens sport. It cannot be done, because they are not there.

A further example of distortion appears in an article in the February 1998 edition of the APC Review, which is the national publication of Australian Parents Council Incorporated. On page seven, an article entitled `Sexuality Discrimination' states that there is no exemption for religious belief. To quote the article:

The original Bill provided an exemption from discrimination in employment for religious educational institutions (including schools) acting in accordance with the tenets, beliefs or teachings of a particular religion or creed, in good faith and to avoid injury to the religious susceptibilities of adherents of that religion or creed.
The Senate Committee recommends no such exemption.

Indeed, they are correct on that. But we did not need to make a recommendation because the committee had agreed to leave the exemptions that were already in the bill dealing with this particular element. We did not recommend their removal. We did not recommend their strengthening or weakening. We did make one important recommendation in regard to religious organisationsâthat if they were receiving Commonwealth funding, they could not discriminate in the distribution of that Commonwealth funding on the basis of the sexuality of a person. It had to be an even distribution, as if the funding was distributed by the Commonwealth itself.

The top of page 7 contains the continuation of an article on page 6, entitled, `The ALP Education Platform'. Unfortunately, the top of page 7 also displays the Australian Labor Party logo, and I understand that it has gone around this house today as being an ALP publication. It is not an ALP publication. It does not make representations about what is and is not contained in the report. It is, in fact, an excerpt from the February 1998 APC Review.

The authors, incidentally, did not seek to make contact with me to check out for themselves whether or not what they were writing was accurate. A lot of people, including some of the more professional journalists around this place, will check out the accuracy of a story before they go to print. This particular organisation did not seek to do that and I think that is a bit disappointing. Following receipt of the transcript of my contribution here tonight, I will send them a copy of what I have had to say and trust that they, in turn, will seek to address and correct the information that they have put out in the publication.

talk.start.para: âA chapter in federal and territory politics ended today, as the resignation of Senator Bob Collins became effective. It is typical of the dichotomy of Bob Collins that he neither made nor sought valedictory comment on his resignation. I would certainly hope that his colleagues in the Labor Party will, on a suitable occasion, make some suitable comment with regard to his resignation.

speech.para: Senator Collins has been both a political adversary and an ally to me during the more than 10 years that we served together in this Senate. As we all know, he is a man of quixotic and often very confusing characteristics. He led us in fierce debate. He displayed good humour and, at times, a very keen pursuit of particular intellectual issues. Whilst Senator Collins's term in the ministry was often controversial, his commitment to the Northern Territory was constant, and we were able in many ways to cooperate on a lot of areas of mutual interest for the Northern Territory. He was always a forceful presence here in the Senate and the absence of his lively debating skills will be noted and, frankly, missed.

Bob Collins was the first federal minister to come from the Northern Territory. He served as shipping minister and minister assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. He was later appointed transport and communications minister and, subsequently, minister for primary industry. He was well respected in Aboriginal communities throughout the Northern Territory. However, he always showed common sense in support of Aborigi nal development, rejecting the policies of the militant Aboriginal and often Labor activists in so many areas. He was not afraid to offend the left wing of his own party by backing increased mining in Aboriginal communities, including the mining of uranium, as he felt it was the will of his Aboriginal communities. He expressed their reservation when that was necessary, as well.

He championed the case of Lindy Chamberlain, which was well known. I know that Bob Collins often cited the eventual quashing of the conviction for the murder of her daughter as the most memorable achievement in his personal career.

On the issue of Northern Territory rights, he was fierce. We again saw this dichotomy in the euthanasia debate when he had to deal with the issue of his own personal views, which were very clearly opposed to euthanasia, and those of supporting territory rights and territory issues where he did champion a very principled stand. I was pleased to be his partner in many of those debates.

As I said before, he had a very good sense of humour and he was certainly unconventional. You might recall the occasion when he threatened to biff Senator Ron Boswell under the ear in a debate, then apologised saying it was just his `friendly territory nature'.

There were parts of Bob Collins's career where he failed to recognise consequences, such as the compounding effects that the airline pilots dispute had on hundreds of small businesses. He stood by while the Commonwealth promised to complete the north-south railway and then made no real progress with that railway whilst he was the transport minister. Of course we all remember the famous occasion when he promised to resign within 12 months if he could not reform the waterfront. Well, some years laterâmuch more than 12 monthsâhe has now resigned, and we still see the problem of union stranglehold in that area. Bob Collins also warned us about the consequences if the Darwin and Alice Springs airports were privatised, but then he did accept his own party's changes on that in a short space of time. We now see those policies effectively being implemented. Of course the pay TV debacle was one debate in this chamber that I am sure many of us remember.

Before coming here, Bob Collins served for 10 years in the Northern Territory Parliament, with five years in the position of Leader of the Opposition. I am sure that he must have found that a very taxing and hard point of view. In the next decade, I hope to form a close personal and non-partisan relationship with Bob Collins as I believe that we both share a great love of and commitment to the Northern Territory.

The final point I make is that the territory will now miss a second voice in this chamber until Senator Collins's replacement has been found. Territory Labor seems to have got itself into a terrible mess over the preselection of a new senatorâto the territory's detriment. It has now been more than seven weeks since Bob Collins announced his intention to resign and, because the ALP has been so indecisive, disorganised and factionally driven, the territory has been left without that second Senate voice to which it is entitledâparticularly as the native title debate resumes this week. Senator Bob Collins obviously did not want to be here for that particular debate because he had strong views that were not consistent with what is currently going on in the tribal warfare of the Labor Party on this particular issue. His commonsense views would not have given him the proper `star witness' role that we would have naturally taxed him on in that particular debate. So the ALP are now asking Territorians to stand back and wait another six weeks. That is a total of 13 weeks without representation in a place that is important. Clearly that is unacceptable.

talk.start.para: âA quarter of a year.

âIt is a quarter of a year. The Labor Party is being extremely inconsistent not only towards its own supporters but also to the electorate in general by leaving Northern Territory voters under-represented in this federal parliament at a very important time. However, tonight, I certainly pay credit to the work and the role of Senator Bob Collins in this place for the last 10 years.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

answer.para: (1) The Commonwealth has sold the South Australian and Tasmanian businesses formerly operated by AN. As such, future capital investment in the rail infrastructure will be the responsibility of the new owners, who have made certain commitments in relation to capital expenditure. However, to assist the development of the rail industry in Tasmania, $5m will be made available for rail infrastructure upgrading in that State.

(2) The Rail Reform Transition Program was introduced in 1996-97, with funding of $10m in each of 1996-97 and 1997-98, to help ameliorate the expected employment losses in regional centres resulting from the sale of losses in regional centres resulting from the sale of AN. The Program has been implemented in consultation with the South Australian and Tasmanian Governments, and community-based advisory committees have been established in both States to make recommendations to the Commonwealth on projects to be funded. the key criterion for projects is their capacity to generate sustainable employment in the private sector.

(3) The administration of AN's redundancy program was in the hands of AN management. AN has advised that it initially took the view that an employee could not receive both invalidity retirement under workers' compensation and redundancy payments. While AN took compensation and redundancy payments. While AN took that view, em ployees with outstanding claims were not retrenched because to do so could have resulted in a `double dip'. Employees who left AN before 267 February 1997 did so of their own volition.

However, AN subsequently received legal advice that an employee may be entitled to both. At a meeting with unions on 26 February 1997, AN indicated that the dual payment would not apply retrospectively ie to employees who had elected to leave AN before that date. However, some employees who left AN after 26 February have received a dual payment.

(4) The An Commission has approved the amendment of the Trust Deed governing the AN principal scheme to provide for the vesting of retirement benefits based on a scale of 20% for each year of membership, which yields full vesting after five years service. In addition, ex-Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme members receive payment of 3 and a half times their equity on the last day of membership of that Scheme, plus vesting as per the amended scale for membership in the AN Principal Scheme. For these members, vesting will include years of membership in both the CSS and the AN Principal Superannuation Scheme. This arrangement will apply retrospectively to 24 November 1996 and, I am advised, is satisfactory to the unions involved.

(5) and (6) The continued employment of any particular group after the sale is the responsibility of the new owner. However, I am advised that all apprentices at Port Augusta were retained in employment after the sale.

(7) Great Southern Railway Ltd (GSR) which has brought AN's passenger business is obliged under the sale agreement to provide five Overland services per week for two years from the date of sale completion, and one Indian Pacific , and one Ghan per week for five years from the date of sale completion. If GSR fails to comply with these requirements, it must pay South Australia a proportion of a `Default Payment Amount" which South Australia has negotiated with GSR. The Commonwealth was not involved in the negotiations and is not aware of the amount. Existing Commonwealth-funded pensioner and Veteran concessions are continuing.

(8) and (9) The routing of its trains, including the Indian Pacific , is the responsibility of their owner, GSR. In negotiations leading to the sale, it was recognised that the buyer would require this flexibility and it was never intended to impose such a condition.

(10) No, such a review has not been undertaken. The Indian Pacific is still running through Broken Hill and the owner has not indicated to the Government any intention to route it away from Broken Hill.

(11) to (13) The land forming the alignment of the track in South Australia and Tasmania has been transferred to those State Governments and leased to the buyers but will revert to the State Governments if not used for railway purposes. However, the track and associated infrastructure has been sold to the new owners.

The Government decided to lease Federal Airports because they are, in the main, significant national and in some cases international infrastructure and so it was appropriate that they be regulated by the Commonwealth Government in accordance with its national responsibilities and international obligations. There was no appropriate regulatory framework in place, and leasehold was seen as a means of achieving this, together with the regime in the Airports Act which the Parliament passed in 1996.

The Commonwealth has retained control of the interstate track, which relates to interstate trade and so is an area of Commonwealth responsibility. The remaining intrastate routes are appropriately regulated by the State Governments.

(14) to (17) The Australian Rail Track Corporation (ARTC) was established on 25 February 1998 pursuant to an inter-governmental agreement signed 14 November 1997 between the Commonwealth and Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia.
(18) Legislation is not required. The ARTC was established under the Corporations Law.
(19) Yes, the company's headquarters will be in Adelaide.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice on 6 February 1998:

question.para: With Reference to the 1997-98 Budget announcement on a deferred retirement plan:

(a) why was 25 hours per week paid employment chosen as the criteria for `work'; (b) given the fact that many part-time workers would be working 3 days a week, what advantages and disadvantages would flow from lowering this level to 24 hours per week; and (c) what would the financial impact be of lowering this level to 24 hours per week.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) The requirement of 25 hours of work each week was originally selected to ensure that people deferring their age pension maintained a high level of workforce attachment.

(b) An advantage flowing from lowering the required hours of work would be that more people would be eligible to participate in the pension bonus scheme. Because only a minor change in the hours worked requirement would be involved, the workforce attachment of persons participating under the Scheme would remain strong.
(c) The financial impact of lowering the required hours of work would be negligible.

Following a series of community consultations that occurred after the Budget announcement last year, the Government has decided to reduce the required number of hours that people participating in the scheme would need to work.

People who wish to participate in the pension bonus scheme will now have to work an average of 20 hours per week over 48 weeks of each year, or 960 hours for a whole year. Paid leave will generally not count as hours worked while participating in the scheme. The 48 week period takes account of normally accepted leave patterns, and allows workers to take up to 4 weeks leave per year without impacting on the work test. This approach treats different leave arrangements consistently and does not favour one style of employment over another.

The 20 hour limit will allow more people to reduce their hours worked in a graduated way as they near retirement; and offers some standardisation with the level required by many States for the issue of State "Seniors" cards.
The financial impact of lowering the required hours of work would be negligible.
